div1.head: Report: Roll of Honor, March 25, 1929
div1.p:
Retained Copy
March 2nd 1929
For Adjutant General
ROLL OF HONOR.

The Secretary of War Hon. Elihu Root in his annual report 1902
said with reference to the conquest of yellow fever in Cuba in 1900 - 1901:

“The brilliant character of this scientific achievement, its
inestimable value to mankind, the saving of thousands of lives, and
the deliverance of the Atlantic seacoast from constant apprehension,
demand special recognition from the Government of the United States.”

The Congress has, in concurrence with this opinion, by an Act
approved February 28th, 1929 authorized and directed the Secretary
of War to publish annually in the Army Register a Roll of Honor on
which shall be carried the following names, and to define in ap-
propriate language the part which each of these persons played in the
experiments during the yellow fever investigations in Cuba.
# MAJOR WALTER REED, Surgeon U.S. Army, born 1851 in Va., died 28 Nov 1902 ✓
President and guiding mind of the Board of Medical Officers which
demonstrated the method of transmission and control of yellow fever.

DR. JAMES CARROLL, ContractActing Assistant Surgeon, later Major Medical Department,
born in England 1854, died 16 Sept. 1907., in Washington.

As a member of the Board he contributed greatly to the success
of the investigation. He was the first to be bitten by infected
mosquitoes and to suffer an attack of experimental yellow fever.

DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR, ContractA. A. Surgeon, U.S. Army, born in Md. 1866,
died 23 September 1900 of yellow fever contracted during his work as
a member of the Board, to the success of whose work he, by his special
knowledge of mosquito infections, greatly contributed.

DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE, ContractA. A. Surgeon, U.S. Army, born in Cuba
-2-
1869, now Professor in the Medical School University of Havana. As a
member of the Board he, by his special laboratory training, contributed
greatly to its success.

✓ JAMES A. ANDRUS, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, volunteered for
experiment and was infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood
of a patient suffering with that disease.

✓ JOHN R. BULLARD, American Civilian, volunteered for experiment and was
infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood of a patient suffer-
ing with that disease.

✓ A. W. COVINGTON, 23 Battery, C.A.C volunteered for experiment and was
infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood of a patient suffer-
ing with that disease.

✓ WILLIAM H. DEAN, Troop B, 7th Cavalry volunteered for experiment and
suffered an attack of yellow fever from the bites of infected mosquitoes.
He died 3 May 1928.

WALLACE W. FORBES, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, volunteered for
experiment and was infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood
of a patient suffering with that disease.

LEVI E. FOLK, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, underwent the trying
ordeal of sleeping twenty nights in the soiled bedding of yellow fever
patients. He also suffered an attack of experimental yellow fever from
the bites of infected mosquitoes.

PAUL HAMANN, Private 23 Battery C.A.C., volunteered for experiment and
was infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood of a patient
suffering with that disease.

JAMES F. HANBERRY, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army underwent the
trying ordeal of sleeping twentynnights in the soiled bedding of
yellow fever patients. He also suffered an attack of experimental
yellow fever from the bites of infected mosquitoes.

WARREN G. JERNEGAN, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, underwent the
trying ordeal of sleeping twenty nights in the soiled bedding of yellow
fever patients. He was then bitten by infected mosquitoes but without
result, and finally suffered an attack of yellow fever by an injection of
blood of a patient suffering with that disease. He died 5 Feb 1919

JOHN R. KISSINGER, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army volunteered for
experiment and suffered an attack of yellow fever from the bites of
infected mosquitoes.

JOHN J. MORAN, Army Civilian Clerk, volunteered for experiment and
suffered an attack of yellow fever from the bites of infected mosquitoes.

WILLIAM OLSEN, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, golunteered for ex-
periment and was infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood of
a patient suffering with that disease.

CHARLES G. SONNTAG, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, volunteered for
experiment and suffered an attack of yellow fever from the bites of
infected mosquitoes.

CLYDE L. WEST, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, volunteered for
experiment and suffered an attack of yellow fever from the bites of
infected mosquitoes.

ROBERT P. COOKE, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army, underwent the
trying ordeal of sleeping twenty nights in the soiled bedding of
yellow fever patients.

THOMAS M. ENGLAND, Private Hospital Corps, now Captain Medical Admini-
strative Corps, U.S. Army, underwent the trying ordeal of sleeping
twenty nights in the soiled bedding of yellow fever patients.

JAMES HILDEBRAND, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, underwent the
trying ordeal of sleeping twenty nights in the soiled bedding of
yellow fever patients. He volunteered to be bitten by infected
mosquitoes, but was not so used.

EDWARD WEATHERWALKS, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, underwent the
trying ordeal of sleeping twenty nights in the soiled bedding of
yellow fever patients. He died 21 Oct. 1916.
